button.title: The Semantic `<button>` Element
button.description: The foundation of any button is the `<button>` tag. It is semantically correct and provides built-in accessibility features that other elements like `<div>` or `<span>` lack. Always use a `<button>` when the user is expected to perform an action on the current page.
button.code:
<!-- A standard button with a descriptive class -->
<button class="btn">Click Me</button>

<!-- A button for submitting a form -->
<form>
  <button type="submit" class="btn">Submit</button>
</form>

<!-- A button that performs an action but doesn't submit -->
<button type="button" class="btn">Open Dialog</button>

modal.title: The Native `<dialog>` Element
modal.description: Using the `<dialog>` element is the modern, semantic way to create modals. It simplifies development and improves accessibility out of the box. The browser automatically handles things like ARIA roles, focus management, and provides a default `::backdrop`. A button is used to trigger the modal's appearance.
modal.code:
Modal Title

This is the modal content.

accordion.title: Structure and Accessibility
accordion.description: The HTML for an accordion must be structured semantically for accessibility. We use headings (`<h2>`), buttons (`<button>`), and a system of ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes to create a component that screen readers can understand and navigate. Key attributes include: `aria-expanded` to inform screen readers if a panel is open or closed; `aria-controls` to programmatically link a button to the panel it controls; `role="region"` and `aria-labelledby` to define the content panel as a landmark region; and the `hidden` attribute to semantically hide the panel from all users.
accordion.code: Content for this section goes here.

headings.title: Semantic Heading Structure
headings.description: HTML provides six levels of headings (h1-h6) to create a clear content hierarchy. The h1 should be used once per page as the main title, with h2-h6 used for subsections in descending order of importance. This semantic structure is crucial for accessibility and SEO.

paragraphs.title: The Paragraph Element
paragraphs.description:
The `

` element represents a paragraph of text. It's a block-level element that automatically adds margins above and below, creating natural spacing between text blocks. Paragraphs should contain related sentences that form a cohesive thought or idea.
paragraphs.code:
This is a standard paragraph. It contains related sentences that discuss a single topic or idea. Paragraphs are the building blocks of readable web content.

Each paragraph should focus on one main idea. When you move to a new concept or topic, start a new paragraph. This makes your content easier to scan and understand.

Paragraphs can contain strong text, emphasized text, and links to other resources.

links.title: Anchor Elements and Link Types
links.description: The `<a>` element creates hyperlinks to other pages, sections within the same page, email addresses, or any other URL. The `href` attribute specifies the link destination. Different types of links serve different purposes and should be marked up appropriately.

lists.description: HTML provides three types of lists: unordered lists (`<ul>`) for items without a specific order, ordered lists (`<ol>`) for sequential items, and description lists (`<dl>`) for term-description pairs. Each serves a specific semantic purpose.

table.title: Semantic Table Structure
table.description: HTML tables should be used exclusively for tabular data. A well-structured table includes a caption, proper headers, and semantic markup that clearly defines the relationship between data cells. The `<thead>`, `<tbody>`, and `<tfoot>` elements provide additional structure.

form.title: Form Structure and Elements
form.description: HTML forms collect user input through various form controls. A well-structured form includes proper labels, fieldsets for grouping related controls, and appropriate input types. The form element wraps all form controls and defines how data is submitted.
form.code:
<form action="/submit" method="post">
  <fieldset>
    <legend>Personal Information</legend>
    
    <label for="name">Full Name:</label>
    <input type="text" id="name" name="name" required>
    
    <label for="email">Email:</label>
    <input type="email" id="email" name="email" required>
    
    <label for="phone">Phone:</label>
    <input type="tel" id="phone" name="phone">
  </fieldset>
  
  <fieldset>
    <legend>Preferences</legend>
    
    <label for="newsletter">
      <input type="checkbox" id="newsletter" name="newsletter">
      Subscribe to newsletter
    </label>
  </fieldset>
  
  <button type="submit">Submit Form</button>
</form>

label.title: Label Element and Associations
label.description: The `<label>` element provides an accessible name for form controls. Labels can be associated with form controls either by wrapping the control or by using the `for` attribute that matches the control's `id`. This association is crucial for accessibility and improves usability.
label.code:
<!-- Explicit association using 'for' attribute -->
<label for="username">Username:</label>
<input type="text" id="username" name="username">

<!-- Implicit association by wrapping -->
<label>
  Password:
  <input type="password" name="password">
</label>

<!-- Labels with required indicators -->
<label for="email">Email Address *</label>
<input type="email" id="email" name="email" required aria-describedby="email-help">
<small id="email-help">We'll never share your email</small>

<!-- Labels for radio buttons and checkboxes -->
<fieldset>
  <legend>Choose your favorite color:</legend>
  <label><input type="radio" name="color" value="red"> Red</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="color" value="blue"> Blue</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="color" value="green"> Green</label>
</fieldset>

input.title: Input Types and Attributes
input.description: The `<input>` element supports numerous types for different kinds of data collection. Modern input types provide built-in validation, specialized keyboards on mobile devices, and better user experience. Attributes like `required`, `pattern`, and `placeholder` enhance functionality.
input.code:
<!-- Text inputs -->
<input type="text" placeholder="Enter your name">
<input type="email" placeholder="Enter your email" required>
<input type="password" placeholder="Enter password" minlength="8">
<input type="tel" placeholder="Phone number" pattern="[0-9]{3}-[0-9]{3}-[0-9]{4}">
<input type="url" placeholder="Website URL">

<!-- Number and date inputs -->
<input type="number" min="1" max="100" step="1">
<input type="date" min="2024-01-01" max="2024-12-31">
<input type="time">
<input type="datetime-local">

<!-- Other input types -->
<input type="file" accept=".jpg,.png,.pdf">
<input type="color" value="#ff0000">
<input type="range" min="0" max="100" value="50">
<input type="search" placeholder="Search...">

<!-- Checkboxes and radio buttons -->
<input type="checkbox" id="agree" name="agree">
<input type="radio" id="option1" name="choice" value="1">

textarea.title: Textarea for Multi-line Input
textarea.description: The `<textarea>` element is used for multi-line text input. Unlike input elements, textarea content goes between opening and closing tags. Attributes like `rows`, `cols`, `minlength`, and `maxlength` control size and validation.
textarea.code:
<!-- Basic textarea -->
<label for="message">Your Message:</label>
<textarea id="message" name="message" rows="4" cols="50" placeholder="Enter your message here..."></textarea>

<!-- Textarea with constraints -->
<label for="bio">Biography (max 500 characters):</label>
<textarea id="bio" name="bio" rows="6" maxlength="500" required placeholder="Tell us about yourself..."></textarea>

<!-- Textarea with default content -->
<label for="code">Code Snippet:</label>
<textarea id="code" name="code" rows="10" cols="80" spellcheck="false">
// Default content goes here
function example() {
  console.log('Hello, World!');
}
</textarea>

<!-- Textarea that doesn't resize -->
<textarea style="resize: none;" rows="3" placeholder="Fixed size textarea"></textarea>

select.title: Select Element and Options
select.description: The `<select>` element creates a dropdown menu of options. Options are defined using `<option>` elements, and related options can be grouped using `<optgroup>`. Select elements can allow single or multiple selections.
select.code:
<!-- Basic select dropdown -->
<label for="country">Country:</label>
<select id="country" name="country" required>
  <option value="">Choose a country</option>
  <option value="us">United States</option>
  <option value="ca">Canada</option>
  <option value="uk">United Kingdom</option>
  <option value="au">Australia</option>
</select>

<!-- Select with option groups -->
<label for="food">Favorite Food:</label>
<select id="food" name="food">
  <optgroup label="Fruits">
    <option value="apple">Apple</option>
    <option value="banana">Banana</option>
    <option value="orange">Orange</option>
  </optgroup>
  <optgroup label="Vegetables">
    <option value="carrot">Carrot</option>
    <option value="broccoli">Broccoli</option>
    <option value="spinach">Spinach</option>
  </optgroup>
</select>

<!-- Multiple selection -->
<label for="skills">Skills (hold Ctrl to select multiple):</label>
<select id="skills" name="skills" multiple size="4">
  <option value="html">HTML</option>
  <option value="css">CSS</option>
  <option value="js">JavaScript</option>
  <option value="react">React</option>
</select>

dropdown.title: Dropdown Menu Structure
dropdown.description: A dropdown menu consists of a trigger element (usually a button) and a menu panel that appears when activated. Proper ARIA attributes ensure the relationship between trigger and menu is clear to assistive technologies. The menu should contain focusable items like links or buttons.

checkbox.title: Accessible Checkbox Structure
checkbox.description: A custom checkbox starts with a semantic `<input type="checkbox">` and its associated `<label>`. The input is visually hidden, and the label acts as the custom-styled checkbox. This ensures the component is fully accessible and keyboard navigable.

radio_group.title: Semantic Radio Group
radio_group.description: Radio buttons must be grouped semantically using a `<fieldset>` and described by a `<legend>`. Each `<input type="radio">` must share the same `name` attribute to ensure they are mutually exclusive. Each input should also have a corresponding `<label>`.
radio_group.code: Select an option:

toggle_switch.title: Toggle Switch from a Button
toggle_switch.description: A toggle switch is an accessible button with a `role="switch"` and an `aria-checked` attribute to indicate its state. A `<span>` inside is used for the visual thumb. This approach provides a great user experience while being fully accessible.

range_slider.title: Range Input with Output
range_slider.description: A standard `<input type="range">` is the foundation. For accessibility and usability, it's best to pair it with a `<label>` and an `<output>` element to display the current value, which is dynamically updated with JavaScript.
range_slider.code: 50

file_upload.title: Drag-and-Drop File Input
file_upload.description: The core is a visually hidden `<input type="file">`. A `<label>` is styled to be the main drop zone. A separate `<div>` is used as a container to display file previews.

date_picker.title: Native Date and Time Inputs
date_picker.description: Leveraging native browser support is the easiest and most accessible way to handle dates and times. Use `<input type="date">`, `<input type="time">`, and `<input type="datetime-local">` for their respective purposes.

search_input.title: Search with Autocomplete
search_input.description: The structure includes a container `div`, an `<input type="search">`, and a `<ul>` for the suggestions list. The list is populated and shown by JavaScript based on user input. ARIA attributes are crucial for accessibility.

multi_select_dropdown.title: Custom Multi-Select Structure
multi_select_dropdown.description: A custom multi-select consists of a wrapper, a button to toggle the dropdown, and a panel containing a list of options (often checkboxes with labels). A separate area may be used to display 'pills' of the selected items.

timeline.title: Timeline Structure
timeline.description: A timeline is semantically an ordered list (`<ol>`) as it represents a sequence of events. Each `<li>` is a timeline item. Inside each item, you can have elements for the time, a title, and a description. The visual line and dots are created with CSS pseudo-elements, keeping the HTML clean.

toast.title: Toast Notification Structure
toast.description: A container element with `position: fixed` is needed to hold all active toasts. Each toast is a `div` with an appropriate `role` (like 'alert' or 'status') for accessibility. Inside, you can include an icon, the message, and an optional close button.

breadcrumbs.title: Breadcrumbs Structure
breadcrumbs.description: Breadcrumbs are implemented as an ordered list (`<ol>`) inside a `<nav>` element with an `aria-label` of 'breadcrumb'. Each `<li>` represents a page in the hierarchy. The last item is marked with `aria-current="page"` to indicate it's the current page and is typically not a link.

sidebar.title: Sidebar Navigation Structure
sidebar.description: A sidebar is typically a `<nav>` or `<aside>` element positioned off-screen. It contains a list of navigation links. A button outside the sidebar is used to toggle its visibility. An overlay `<div>` is also included to cover the main content when the sidebar is open, especially on mobile.

pagination.title: Pagination Structure
pagination.description: Pagination is structured as a `<nav>` element containing a list of links. The links can be page numbers or directional arrows (Previous/Next). The current page is marked with `aria-current="page"` and styled differently. Disabled links have an `aria-disabled="true"` attribute.
pagination.code: Previous 1 2 3 ... 10 Next

stepper.title: Stepper / Wizard Structure
stepper.description: A stepper is an ordered list (`<ol>`) where each `<li>` is a step. ARIA attributes like `aria-current="step"` are used to indicate the active step. The content for each step is in separate panels, and control buttons (Next/Previous) are used to navigate between them.

progress_bar.title: Progress Bar (Accessible Determinate/Indeterminate)
progress_bar.description: A semantic progress bar with ARIA attributes for screen readers. The container uses `role="progressbar"` along with `aria-valuemin`, `aria-valuemax`, and `aria-valuenow`. Nested `.progress-fill` visually reflects the current value with a smooth transition. For indeterminate state, omit `aria-valuenow` and apply a CSS animation to `.progress-fill`.
